;;自哈马斯武装分子在以色列南部肆虐以来，以色列步兵周五首次袭击加沙地带，以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡表示，报复行动才刚刚开始。阿尔蒙德·李报道。;
;

;以色列在告诉居住在人口稠密地区的巴勒斯坦人向南逃往与以色列关闭的边境后，准备于周六对哈马斯控制的加沙地带发动地面攻击。埃及。

;

;与此同时，以色列国家安全顾问警告黎巴嫩激进组织真主党不要在以色列北部的第二战线发动战争，并威胁称，如果这样做，将“摧毁黎巴嫩”。

;

;以色列发誓要消灭控制加沙的哈马斯激进组织，以报复其;武装分子;一周前冲进以色列城镇，枪杀平民并劫持数十名人质，这是以色列历史上对平民最严重的袭击。

;

;大约 1,300 人人们在一场残酷的袭击中丧生，这让以色列深感震惊，无论是杀戮的规模，还是令人震惊的手机录像，以及医疗和紧急服务部门关于被占领的城镇和基布兹暴行的报告。

;< p>;作为回应，以色列飞机和大炮对加沙进行了有史以来最猛烈的轰炸，使这片居住着 230 万巴勒斯坦人的飞地陷入全面围困。

;

;加沙当局称，有超过 2,200 人被困已被杀，其中四分之一是儿童，近万人受伤。救援人员拼命寻找夜间空袭的幸存者。

;

;周六，数千名巴勒斯坦人逃离了加沙地带北部，逃离了以色列预计的地面袭击路线，而以色列则对该地区进行了更多的空袭和打击。表示保留了两条道路，以便人们逃生。

;

;哈马斯领导人伊斯梅尔·哈尼亚表示，尽管据报道自以色列开始轰炸以来已有一百万加沙居民逃离家园，但巴勒斯坦人将“留在我们的土地上”。

;

;哈马斯 10 月 7 日的突然袭击使该地区陷入了一场新的危机，愤怒的以色列领导人准备以镇压性的武力予以回应。

;

;“以色列国防军 (IDF) 士兵和军方在一份声明中表示：“各营部署在全国各地，正在加强战争下一阶段的作战准备，重点是重大地面行动。”军方在一份声明中表示，这将包括空中、海上行动周五，以色列军方告诉加沙地带北半部的居民，其中包括飞地最大的定居点加沙城，立即向南移动。周六，它表示将保证在下午 4:00（格林威治标准时间 1300）之前逃离两条主要道路的巴勒斯坦人的安全。随着最后期限的过去，军队正在加沙周围集结。

;

;哈马斯告诉人们不要离开，并表示出去的道路不安全。据称，周五载有难民的汽车和卡车遭到袭击，造成数十人死亡，但路透社无法独立核实这一消息。以色列称，哈马斯正在阻止人们离开，将他们用作人体盾牌，但哈马斯对此予以否认。

;

;在加沙城的 Tel Al-Hawa 社区，在以色列下令撤离的地区，战机在夜间轰炸了一个居民区据在附近圣城医院避难的居民说，几栋房屋遭到袭击。

;

;“我们度过了一个恐怖的夜晚。以色列因为我们不愿离开家园而惩罚我们。还有比这更残酷的暴行吗？一位三个孩子的父亲在医院接受电话采访时表示，由于担心遭到报复，他拒绝透露姓名。

;

;“我宁愿死也不离开，但我不能看到我的妻子和孩子死去”

;

;巴勒斯坦红新月会表示，它已收到以色列在下午 4:00 之前撤离医院的命令，但它不会这样做，因为它有继续向巴勒斯坦人提供服务的人道义务。

;

;在加沙地带南部的汗尤尼斯，以色列飞机连夜袭击了一栋四层楼的建筑，邻居们纷纷赶去营救人员。

;

;一名加沙记者拍摄了救护人员正在寻找夜间空袭的幸存者。可以看到一名护理人员走进一条被头灯照亮的小巷，这时另一次袭击发出的巨大闪光在他面前爆发。当飞机在上空呼啸而过时，医务人员冲进救护车并迅速离开。一名受伤的医务人员尖叫道：“我的眼睛！我的眼睛！”

;

;对以色列的袭击使该国陷入深深的悲痛，并激发了战争，几天之内就动员了数十万预备役军人。

;

; >;

;被绑架的以色列人的家人对他们的安全感到恐惧。阿维猜·布罗德茨 (Avichai Brodetz) 是卡法阿扎基布兹 (Kibbutz Kfar Aza) 的农民，他的妻子和三个孩子被俘虏到加沙，他在以色列军队总部外设立了一个营地，以关注他们的困境。

;

;“首先需要做的是发生的事情是释放妇女和儿童，”他告诉记者。

;

;哈马斯武装部门表示，由于以色列的空袭，包括四名外国人在内的九名俘虏在一夜之间被杀害。此前，它曾威胁说，以色列在没有警告的情况下袭击每一座建筑物，就会杀死一名人质。

;

;以色列对加沙的袭击未能阻止哈马斯深入以色列城市的导弹袭击。周六，以色列中部响起空袭警报，火箭弹击中阿什凯隆的温室，导致基布兹的四人受伤。

;

;离开加沙的唯一不受以色列控制的路线是拉法与埃及的检查站。埃及官方表示其一侧是开放的，但由于以色列的袭击，交通已中断数天。埃及安全部门消息人士称，埃及方面正在增援，开罗无意接受大量涌入的难民。

;

;美国国务院官员表示，美国正在努力于周六开放过境点，让一些难民进入开罗。并与想要离开加沙的巴勒斯坦裔美国人取得了联系。华盛顿后来;表示;它已经告知其公民试图到达过境点。

;

;各国和援助机构已向埃及发送物资，但迄今为止无法将其带入加沙。以色列表示，未经其协调，任何东西都不能通过拉法进入。

;

;以色列表示，其撤离令是一种人道主义姿态，旨在保护居民，同时铲除哈马斯武装分子。联合国表示，在不造成人道主义灾难的情况下，无法将这么多人安全转移到被围困的飞地内。

;

;哈马斯发誓要战斗到流尽最后一滴血，并表示已下令离开该地区北部飞地是迫使居民放弃家园的伎俩。

;

;自 2006 年以来，加沙的暴力事件伴随着以色列北部边境与黎巴嫩最严重的冲突，引发了人们对战争蔓延到另一条战线的担忧。< /p>;

;黎巴嫩武装真主党运动是哈马斯等伊朗的亲密盟友，该组织表示，他们使用制导导弹和迫击炮弹向有争议的沙巴阿农场地区的五个以色列前哨基地开火。

;

;路透社看到了导弹向以色列军队哨所开枪，听到以色列的炮击和枪声。

;

;以色列 Kan 电台报道称，由于涉嫌来自黎巴嫩的入侵，五个边境村庄已被封锁。

;

;Prime本杰明·内塔尼亚胡部长的安全顾问查奇·哈内格比表示，以色列“试图不陷入两条战线的战争”，并警告真主党不要卷入战斗。

;

;“我们希望真主党事实上不会卷入这场战争” ，带来黎巴嫩的毁灭，因为如果那里爆发战争，结果也不会少，”他说，暗指以色列长期以来威胁要对该国发动猛烈打击，以阻止真主党发射大规模导弹军火库。

;

;华盛顿还决心确保伊朗和伊朗支持的团体（例如黎巴嫩真主党）不会卷入冲突。

;;在以色列呼吁收容超过 100 万平民后，在以色列袭击中逃离家园的巴勒斯坦人在一所联合国开办的学校避难2023 年 10 月 14 日，加沙地带北部的汗尤尼斯向南移动。路透社/Ahmed Zakot;

;当以色列告诉加沙居民离开人口稠密的巴勒斯坦地区的家园时90 岁的法齐亚·沙欣 (Fawziya Shaheen) 回忆起在巴勒斯坦人意识中烙印的黑暗篇章。

;

;离开或被赶出他们想要建立自己的土地的想法当许多巴勒斯坦人;逃离时，该国的状态与“Nakba”或“灾难”相呼应。或在 1948 年以色列建国战争期间被迫离开家园。

;

;“无论发生什么，我们都不会流离失所。他们袭击了我们，但我们不会离开家园，也不会流离失所，”沙欣和她的孙子们坐在家里，面临以色列无情的轰炸、面包、饮用水短缺和停电。

;<以色列已要求加沙地带北半部的居民在周六早上之前向南迁移。随后又表示，将在下午 4:00（格林威治标准时间 1300）之前保证在两条主要道路上逃亡的巴勒斯坦人的安全。过去了，;部队正在加沙地带周围集结;。; p>;

;“我记得我们第一次流离失所的时候以及现在发生在我们身上的事情。这都是美国和与犹太人（以色列）实现正常化的国家的错，”住在汗尤尼斯难民营内的一条小巷里的沙欣说。

;

;“即使美国、以色列或任何其他国家干预，我们都会留在原地，我们不会离开家园。”

;

;Shaheen 最初是从 Al-Majdal 流离失所，最后来到贫困的加沙，现在是世界上人口最稠密的地方之一. 她亲眼目睹了 1948 年、1956 年、1967 年、1973 年的战争以及以色列与巴勒斯坦激进组织哈马斯之间的冲突。

;

;大约 70 万巴勒斯坦人（英国统治下的巴勒斯坦阿拉伯人口的一半）被剥夺了财产，流离失所，许多人涌入邻国阿拉伯国家，他们或他们的许多后裔仍留在那里。许多人仍然住在难民营中。

;

;以色列对驱逐巴勒斯坦人的说法提出质疑，称以色列在之后遭到五个阿拉伯国家的袭击它的创造。

;

;以色列发动了;猛烈轰炸;，发誓要消灭控制加沙的哈马斯武装组织，以报复其武装人员的暴行，这些武装分子 ;一周前袭击以色列城镇;，枪杀平民并劫持数十名人质。约 1,300 人在以色列历史上最严重的针对平民的袭击中丧生。

;

;以色列表示，疏散令是一种人道主义姿态，旨在保护居民免受伤害，同时铲除哈马斯武装分子。联合国表示，在不造成人道主义灾难的情况下，无法将如此多的人安全转移到被围困的飞地内。

;

;Ukraine is finding it harder to secure financial support as the attention of officials in key donor countries shifts to upcoming elections and geopolitical tensions heighten, Finance Minister Serhiy Marchenko told Reuters on Saturday.

;

;"I see a lot of tiredness, I see a lot of weakness among our partners, they would like to forget about the war but the war is still ongoing, full-scale," Marchenko said on the sidelines of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank meetings in Marrakech.

;He said Ukraine is making "twice the effort right now to convince our partners to provide us with support compared to the last annual meetings" in April.

;

;As the war with Russia rages on, Ukraine needs to secure Western financial support to cover a $43 billion budget gap in 2024. Talks this week have been overshadowed by the conflict between Israel and Hamas, which broke out just as delegates were making their way to Marrakech.

;

;Marchenko said "a geopolitical shift and internal political context in different countries" was dampening governments' appetite to support Ukraine, mentioning elections scheduled in the US and the European Union next year.

;

;Ukraine has earmarked additional tax receipts and funds to be raised from internal debt, but it will be dependent on outside help for the bulk of next year's spending requirements.

;

;"We already have some commitments, like $5.4 billion from the IMF programme, and we expect commitments from Japan and United Kingdom, and of course, we rely on our key partners and allies the United States and European Union," Marchenko said in the interview.

;

;The EU is working on a 50 billion-euro ($52.6 billion)Ukraine package for 2024 through 2027. Marchenko said Ukraine is seeking 18 billion euros of that in 2024, matching the package received for this year.

;

;Marchenko welcomed the efforts to harness frozen Russian state assets, saying that what was previously portrayed by Western backers as an "achievable goal" now "sounds like a plan". Legal concerns, among others, have complicated recoveries.

;

;Since Moscow's February 2022 invasion, most of Ukraine's bilateral lenders have suspended repayment obligations until 2027, and the country has agreed a two-year freeze on $20 billion of international bonds that runs through August.

;

;Ukraine has been sounding out major investors over plans to ;restructure; the international debt and the possibility of raising fresh financing, Reuters reported on Oct. 9, citing people with knowledge of the discussions.

;

;"We have some time to prepare discussions with private creditors," Marchenko said, declining to provide a timeframe on when formal talks with creditors may start.

;

;"Our natural desire is to preserve access to the market," he added.

;

;Marchenko said credit enhancement notes could be "one of the ways" to raise funds, but that how such guarantees would work depends on the future of Ukraine's growth, among other economic factors. This has not been a topic of discussion at the meetings in Marrakech, he said.

;

;Ukraine's economy is set to grow 5% in 2024, Marchenko told the meetings earlier this week, and sufficient gas storage for the winter should buttress the economy from a potential rise in prices, he told Reuters.

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 23:55:03 +0800 Key takeaways from the IMF/World Bank meetingshttps://reuters.com/article/imf-worldbank-meeting/key-takeaways-from-the-imf-world-bank-meetings-idUSKBN31E09I
;;2023-10-14T15:11:41Z;
;;
;;World Bank President Ajay Banga, World Bank Secretary Mercy Tembon, Ukraine Minister of Finance Serhiy Marchenko, International Monetary Fund (IMF) Secretary Ceda Ogada and Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Kristalina Georgieva preside over the annual meeting's plenary during the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, following last month's deadly earthquake, in Marrakech, Morocco, October 13, 2023. REUTERS/Susana Vera;
;

;Overshadowed by fresh Middle East violence and hosted by a country still recovering from an earthquake, the week-long annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank wrapped up on Saturday.

;

;Discussions in the Moroccan city of Marrakech ranged from the prospects for a world economy weighed down by debt, inflation and conflict to the growing wealth gap between rich and poor countries and floundering efforts to tackle climate change.

;

;Here are the main takeaways:

;

;The new IMF ;outlook; - signed off before the escalation of the conflict between Israel and Hamas - sees global economic growth slowing from 3.5% last year to 3% this year and 2.9% next year, a 0.1% point downgrade from a previous 2024 estimate.

;

;Global inflation is seen dropping from 6.9% this year to a still-high 5.8% next. Central bankers ;signalled; readiness to end interest rate hikes if events allow, hopeful that inflation can be finally tamed without too hard a landing.

;

;Most agreed it was too early to say how Middle East strife would affect a global economy which IMF chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas described as "limping along, not sprinting".

;

;The heavy debt burdens of advanced economies - from the United States to China and Italy - was a recurrent theme in the meetings, which came after financial markets in recent weeks pushed US bond yields higher. Italian central bank governor Ignazio Visco said there was an impression markets were "reevaluating the term premium" as investors become more nervous about holding longer term debt.

;

;JPMorgan chair of global research Joyce Chang put it another way. "The bond vigilantes are back, and the Great Moderation is over," she told a panel of the two-decade era of relative economic calm before the 2008/09 financial crisis.

;

;One policy area where this could have a knock-on effect is the fight against climate change.国际货币基金组织财政部门负责人维托尔·加斯帕警告称，当前基于补贴的政策未能实现净零排放，扩大政策范围将导致公共债务激增。 "Countries will need a new mix of policies with carbon pricing at the centre," the Fund concluded.

;

;Looking beyond the major developed economies, higher policy rates, a strong dollar and geopolitical uncertainties are adding to challenges for the rest of the world.

;

;Turkey was in the spotlight as Finance Minister Mehmet Simsek pitched its reform plan. "The biggest structural issue is to bring inflation down. And they're working on it," said Murat Ulgen, Global Head of Emerging Markets Research at HSBC.

;

;Kenya is looking to avoid slipping into debt distress and its central bank governor ;told Reuters; it plans a buyback of a quarter of its $2 billion international bond maturing in June - pushing its 2024 bond up 1.2 cents on the dollar.

;

;One debt restructuring deal emerged: ;Zambia; finally agreed a debt rework memorandum of understanding with creditors including China and France.

;

;Progress on Sri Lanka was less clear. Sri Lanka said on Thursday it reached an agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China covering about $4.2 billion of debt, while talks with other official creditors are stalling.

;

;High interest rates will put some borrowers in more precarious positions, the IMF warned in its Global Financial Stability Report. Around 5% of banks globally are ;vulnerable; to stress if those rates remain higher for longer, it estimated, and a further 30% of banks - including some of the world's largest - would be vulnerable if the global economy enters a prolonged period of low growth and high inflation.

;

;The Ukraine war, growing trade protectionism and tensions between the United States and China are all making consensus-building tougher: In the end, there was not enough agreement to issue the usual final communique at the end of the meetings.

;

;There was much talk ahead of Marrakech on revamping the IMF and World Bank to better reflect the emergence of economies like China and Brazil.美国提出的一项增强国际货币基金组织贷款能力但保留对该基金持股审查的提议赢得了广泛支持。 A ;pact; announced on Saturday spoke of a "meaningful increase" in quotas by end-2023 but gave few other details. Anti-poverty groups were sceptical of what had been achieved.

;

;"The big theme this week is G7 countries papering over the cracks of shattered promises," said Kate Donald, Head of Oxfam International's Washington DC Office. "Despite the wringing of hands about the billions of dollars needed to tackle poverty and climate breakdown, there has been no sign of new money."
